page.title: 07Tourism
page.content: Bradford-on-Avon was populated by Ancient Britons from earliest times. The Romans settled here from A.D.80 until A.D.450. A Roman villa was uncovered when our new comprehensive school was being built. The Saxons built a church in our town in about 700A.D. Our town's name is pure Anglo Saxon, "Broad Ford." The Vikings attacked the Abbess of Shaftesbury's monastry here. Alfred the Great battled with the Vikings and King Canute attacked the town.{ { 1086-Domesday Book-Bradford-on-Avon {valued at Â£60. Population 400. We have a famous and magnificent 13th century tithe barn, a unique 14th century bridge upon which sits a, "chapel," which used to be the town prison. Tourists flock to the town in thousands, particularly in the Summer months.
